messages.title: Hammersmith Constituency Key Facts
messages.content: UNEMPLOYMENT DOWN: 1,700 fewer people in the Hammersmith parliamentary constituency claiming Jobseeker's Allowance compared to 2010 - a 48.4% fall. MORE APPRENTICESHIPS: 2,020 people in the Hammersmith constituency have started an apprenticeship since the 2010 General Election. LOWER TAX ALL: 5,540 people in Hammersmith are out of income tax altogether. The big tax cut benefits people earning less than £15,600 from 10/6/15. MORE NEW JOBS: 21,600 Hammersmith and London residents have found one since 2010.

messages.title: THE CHOICE AT THIS ELECTION IS BETWEEN ECONOMIC COMPETENCE AND GROWTH UNDER THE CONSERVATIVES; OR A RETURN TO CHAOS AND UNCERTAINTY WITH LABOUR.

keyPolicies.policyDescription: Local unemployment is down 45%; 2,020 people with 1,770 new benefits and 2,010 new apprenticeships. Working with a strong economy can create jobs.
Reduce income tax by raising the personal allowance to £12,500 and raising the point where you pay the 40% rate from £42,285 to £50,000.
Maintaining the success of the six Free Schools and getting even greater future choice for parents and children under the local government.
Build affordable homes to buy through Discount Market Sales and Shared Ownership, helping local people onto the property ladder.
From autumn 2015, a Conservative government would meet 20% of childcare costs for working families with children under 12.
Endorsing the £150 million investment to improve Charing Cross Hospital whilst holding the NHS to account, to access A&E and the best local technology available.
Rejecting the third runway, whilst ensuring that Heathrow remains the world's hub airport.
Replace the Hammersmith Flyover with a tunnel from Hogarth Roundabout to Earls Court to reconnect Hammersmith to the river.

issues.economy: Capping benefits & making work pay. Since 2010, benefits capped at £500/week for couples and £350/week for single people without children. Local economy is a serious issue.
issues.education: Maintaining the success of the six Free Schools and getting even greater future choice for parents and children under the local government.
issues.health: Endorsing the £150 million investment to improve Charing Cross Hospital whilst holding the NHS to account, to access A&E and the best local technology available.
issues.socialWelfare: Capping benefits & making work pay. Since 2010, benefits capped at £500/week for couples and £350/week for single people without children.

housing.content: Build affordable homes to buy through Discount Market Sales and Shared Ownership, helping local people onto the property ladder.

leaflet.personalStatement: I grew up in Yorkshire, moved to Edinburgh University and then went into international marketing. Now a Hammersmith local, I am passionate about representing its residents, that broad response to be transformed within London and those amazing local communities. Chair of the Community and Children's Services of the National Adoption Society and delivering British, World and Paralympic Championship events.

images.caption: Charlie Dewhirst with Prime Minister David Cameron.
Charlie discussing improvements to King Street with a local coffee owner.
Charlie visiting the Work Zone, which has helped 1,089 local people back into work since 2010.
